stem: A 36-year-old client is 12 hours post-tibial plateau reconstruction. He has an active epidural for pain relief. Based on the documentation in the Post-Surgical Anesthesia & Muscle Vitality Log tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition and the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Rule out silent compartment syndrome in a patient with a sensory block.
Background: Extensive orthopedic reconstruction. Epidural Bupivacaine/Fentanyl infusion.
Assessment: Right lower leg is significantly larger than the left and feels 'hard as a rock.' Client reports 0/10 pain.
Recommendation: Maneuver pressure check.

tabs.title: Vital Signs
tabs.content: BP 122/78, HR 82, RR 18, T 98.6Â°F. Pedal pulses are bounding.

conditionOptions.text: Post-Operative Edema with effective Epidural block

actionOptions.text: Immediately notify the orthopedic surgeon of the 36 mmHg pressure
Maintain the limb at the level of the heart (NOT elevated)
Increase the epidural rate to further improve the client's comfort
Massage the calf vigorously to reduce the hardness

parameterOptions.text: Intracompartmental pressure (mmHg) and Delta Pressure (MAP - ICP)
Peripheral pulses and motor function distal to the injury
Daily measurement of fasting serum glucose
Presence of a positive Babinski sign

rationale.correct: This is Silent Acute Compartment Syndrome (c2), masked by epidural anesthesia. Because the patient cannot feel the 'Pain out of Proportion' (due to the sensory block), the nurse must rely on objective cues like the manometry pressure (36 mmHg) and the 'rock-hard' tension of the limb. Priority #1 is notifying the surgeon for a likely fasciotomy (a1) and Priority #2 is maintaining neutral positioning (a2) to optimize perfusion. Parameters focus on the objective pressure (p1) and pulses/motor status (p2).
clinicalPearls: Epidurals and nerve blocks are a major safety risk for compartment syndrome because they remove the earliest warning sign (Pain).
Pulse checks are UNRELIABLE in compartment syndrome; the pressure stops capillary flow long before it stops the large arteries.
A pressure of > 30 mmHg in the fascia is an absolute surgical emergency.

questionTrap.trap: Assuming everything is fine because the 'Pulse is bounding' and 'Pain is 0/10'.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: If the muscle is hard as a rock and the pressure is 36, it doesn't matter if they have a pulse or no pain; the muscle is dying. Always trust the manometry over the patient's report in this scenario.

mnemonic.title: Silent Savior
mnemonic.expansion: S-Stiff muscle. I-Increased manometry. L-Level positioning. E-Emergency fasciotomy. N-Notified surgeon. T-Trust the machine.
